1. Provide step-by-step instructions: Teachers can create instructional materials that explain how to use various technological tools and platforms that are commonly used in the classroom. These can include how-to videos, PDF documents, and walkthroughs that explain the features and functionality of the tools.

2. Assign technology buddies: Teachers can pair up students who are experienced with a particular technology with students who are new to it. This way, the more experienced student can serve as a mentor and provide guidance and support to their partner.

3. Create online tutorials and resources: Teachers can create online tutorials and resources that are available to students anytime, anywhere. These can include video tutorials, interactive quizzes, and other resources that can help students learn how to use the technology.

4. Encourage experimentation and exploration: Teachers can encourage students to explore and experiment with new technologies. By giving them the freedom to try new tools and platforms, students can develop their technological skills and discover new ways to learn.

5. Provide regular training sessions: Teachers can offer regular training sessions that focus on different aspects of using technology in the classroom. These sessions can be scheduled at regular intervals, such as once a week or once a month, and can cover topics such as using online collaboration tools or creating multimedia presentations.
